person.persName: George C. Castleman (Louisville merchant and Henry County farmer)

body.p: A Kentucky steamboat captain, merchant/grocer, and farmer. Lived in Jefferson County, Kentucky in 1860. Received a private school education. Moved to New Albany, Indiana to work at a saw mill with his brother-in-law. Started work for his brother, C. G. Castleman, as a clerk aboard the steamer Herold. Worked in various positions until he became commander of the Gen. Wayne in 1835. Subsequently served as commander of the Robert Morris and the Ben Franklin. Served as captain of the Sherrod in 1837, on which his father died. Retired from the river life and returned to the family homestead in Woodford County, Kentucky. Married twice, first to Jane C. Torbitt Castleman, and on a second occasion to Mary J. Brinker Gist Castleman. Father of Samuel Castleman, Martha Castleman, David Castleman, and Josephine Castleman. Following the death of his first wife, he briefly moved to Texas and engaged in the trading of cattle. Returned to Kentucky in 1857 and worked as a wholesale grocer with his brother-in-law J. P. Torbitt in the firm Castleman & Torbitt located in Louisville, Kentucky until 1861. Remarried in 1859. He relocated to Henry County, Kentucky and bought farmland tied to his second wife's family. Owned twelve enslaved persons in 1860. Member of the Christian Chruch in Henry County. Member of the Whig Party until its demise.
